newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Tenaga sees good results this year.
newsitem.headline: Tenaga sees good results this year.

text.p: Malaysia's power utility said the recent increase in electricity tariff and subsidy for its gas purchase were expected to have a positive impact on its financial results this year.
However, foreign exchange losses from interest repayment on offshore loans as a result of recent sharp drop in the ringgit could put a dent on profits, he said.

Tenaga's head of investor relation unit Khairunnizam Naharudin said while the company's foreign exchange exposure was only a book value that would not affect cash flow, it would still result in a "little downside".

"Forex is a paper loss. If you exclude it from our positive announcements on the gas subsidy and tariff, and compare it with our 1996 results, it will be a good year for Tenaga," he told reporters after Tenaga's briefing for analysts.
But he said analysts' forecast of a 1.159 billion ringgit net profit was "too high".

Tenaga reported a net profit of 797.8 million ringgit for the year ended August 31, 1996, down 36 percent from 1.24 billion in the previous year. For the six months to end-February 1997, it posted a net profit of 511 million ringgit against 370 million in the previous corresponding period.

In May, the government approved a tariff adjustment increasing the average rate by 8.3 percent. The government had also fixed the gas price at 6.40 ringgit per metric million British thermal unit until the year 2000.

As at end-February this year, Tenaga's total loans amounted to $4.06 billion, of which ringgit loans comprised 54 percent, U.S. dollar 33 percent, yen 10 percent, sterling two percent and others one percent.
